skill.name: gget
skill.description: CLI/Python toolkit for rapid bioinformatics queries. Preferred for quick BLAST searches. Access to 20+ databases: gene info (Ensembl/UniProt), AlphaFold, ARCHS4, Enrichr, OpenTargets, COSMIC, genome downloads. For advanced BLAST/batch processing, use biopython. For multi-database integration, use bioservices.
skill.summary: CLI/Python toolkit for rapid bioinformatics queries. Preferred for quick BLAST searches. Access to 2...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Documentation wrapper for established open-source bioinformatics library. All patterns flagged are legitimate tool functionality: CLI command examples in docs, URLs to public genomic databases, and optional OpenAI API integration. No malicious behavior detected. gget is an academic tool from UC Berkeley's Pachter lab.

content.user_title: Query genomic databases and analyze sequences
content.value_statement: Need quick access to gene information, protein structures, or expression data? This skill provides unified access to 20+ bioinformatics databases through a single interface. Search genes, retrieve sequences, predict structures, and analyze disease associations without switching tools.
actual_capabilities: Search genes by name or description across 20+ genomic databases
Retrieve nucleotide and protein sequences from Ensembl and UniProt
Query tissue expression and gene correlation data from ARCHS4
Perform enrichment analysis using Enrichr and KEGG pathways
Get disease and drug associations from OpenTargets
limitations: Requires Python installation and gget package (pip install gget)
Some modules require additional setup (AlphaFold, ELM, cellxgene)
Network connectivity required for database queries
Rate limits apply to API-based databases

use_cases.title: Gene information lookup
use_cases.description: Quickly find gene details, sequences, and functional annotations from unified searches

use_cases.title: Pathway enrichment analysis
use_cases.description: Perform functional enrichment on gene lists using multiple ontology databases

use_cases.title: Target prioritization
use_cases.description: Identify disease-associated genes and existing drugs targeting them

prompt_templates.title: Find a gene
prompt_templates.prompt: Find information about the [GENE_NAME] gene in human including its sequence, function, and disease associations

prompt_templates.title: Compare sequences
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare the protein sequences of [GENE_A] and [GENE_B] using MUSCLE alignment and identify conserved regions

prompt_templates.title: Expression analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Get tissue expression data for [GENE_NAME] and find genes with similar expression patterns

prompt_templates.title: Drug target research
prompt_templates.prompt: Identify drugs associated with [GENE_NAME] and its disease associations from OpenTargets

output_examples.input: Find information about TP53 including its sequence, protein structure, and disease associations
output: â€¢ Description: Tumor protein p53 - a tumor suppressor protein
â€¢ Tissue expression: Highest in testis, esophagus, and tongue
â€¢ Top disease associations: Malignant neoplasm of colon, Lung adenocarcinoma (scores > 0.9)
â€¢ Associated drugs: Doxorubicin, Cisplatin, Nutlin-3 (various trial phases)
â€¢ Nucleotide sequence: 1179 bp coding sequence available

best_practices: Specify species (homo_sapiens, mus_musculus) for accurate gene matching
Use Ensembl IDs for precise queries when gene symbols are ambiguous
Save results with output flags for reproducibility in workflows
Update gget regularly to match changing database structures
anti_patterns: Using gene symbols without species specification when symbols may overlap
Querying more than 1000 Ensembl IDs at once (may cause server errors)
Skipping error handling in automated analysis pipelines
Ignoring database version specifications for reproducibility

faq.question: What databases does gget access?
faq.answer: gget queries 20+ databases including Ensembl, UniProt, NCBI, PDB, ARCHS4, Enrichr, OpenTargets, cBioPortal, COSMIC, and AlphaFold

faq.question: Does gget work with Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes, gget works as a Python library in Claude Code. Install with pip and import gget in your analysis scripts

faq.question: What programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: gget provides both command-line interface and Python API. The Python API returns pandas DataFrames for easy data manipulation

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: Yes, gget queries public genomic databases over HTTPS. No user data is stored. Sequence queries are sent to NCBI BLAST and other APIs

faq.question: How do I handle rate limits?
faq.answer: Implement delays between queries (1-2 seconds), use local databases (DIAMOND, COSMIC) for large-scale work, and cache results

faq.question: How does gget compare to Biopython?
faq.answer: gget provides unified access to 20+ databases through simple commands, while Biopython offers more sequence manipulation tools. Use both together for comprehensive analysis
